title: Family claim a 16-month-old toddler was STRIP SEARCHED by a cop in New South Wales
text:
A 16-month-old toddler visiting his father in a New South Wales jail was allegedly strip searched by a female cop.

The child is suing the state through his mother, after he was allegedly taken from his aunt's car and into a police bus near Kempsey Jail, on New South Wales' Mid North Coast, on September 2, 2018.

Court documents said his family allege the female officer examined the child's body and genitals after undressing his clothes and nappy, The Daily Telegraph reported.

A 16-month-old toddler visiting his father in a New South Wales jail was allegedly strip searched by a female cop (stock image)

In New South Wales, strip searches cannot be conducted on a person who is under the age of 10 years.

The family are making a claim for exemplary damages in legal action at the NSW District Court.

According to the family's documents, the officer 'outrageously and disgracefully' strip searched the child and the act had a 'flagrant disregard' for the law and 'affronts morality'.

The female cop accused of searching the toddler was internally investigated by police and two complaints were upheld, including that it is illegal to strip search a child under 10.

NSW Police and Corrective Services were conducting a screening operation outside the jail during the time of the alleged strip search.

The search was targeting the smuggling of contraband into detention. Daily Mail Australia does not suggest the family were using the child to commit an offence or that they were committing any other kind of offence.

Lawyers for the child Todd Scott and Dean Woodbury said the alleged incident was a violation of basic human rights.

'Strip searching a one-year-old child is a disgraceful violation of someone who … is completely incapable of asserting or defending their basic human rights,' Mr Scott told The Daily Telegraph.

'Unlawful strip searching appears to be rampant among NSW Police officers and something must be done urgently to stop this. Either there is deficient or insufficient training around this.'

The toddler is suing the state through the tutelage of his mother, after he was allegedly taken from his aunt's car and into a police bus near Kempsey Jail, in the Mid North Coast, on September 2, 2018 about 10am (stock image)

Police have not yet filed a defence to the court and cannot comment on whether the female officer has been disciplined.

A NSW Police spokesman said: 'As there are civil proceedings current, it is not appropriate that the NSW Police Force comments.'

The child's 17-year-old aunt is also suing amid claims she was illegally strip searched during the prison visit.

Her statement of claim says their was a breach of the law as a minor can only be strip searched in the company of a parent, guardian or acceptable third party.

The case is scheduled for a call over hearing at Port Macquarie District Court in November.
